Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge correctly applied the residency requirement under section 5(1) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant Li Zhang established residence on October 2, 2002, and accumulated 922 days of residence in Canada within four years before application, falling short of the required 1095 days
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application denied due to failure to meet residency requirements
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Citizenship Judgeâ€™s decision
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship Judge applied qualitative test but found quantitative deficiency dispositive
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged incorrect application of residency requirement by Citizenship Judge
Assessment_Factor: Number of days of physical residence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review proceedings in Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Record of residence dates and duration in Canada
Application_Basis: Failure to meet minimum 1095-day physical presence requirement
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation supporting claimed days of residence
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Citizenship Judge's decision and approval of citizenship application
Governing_Rule: Applicants must have at least 1095 days of residence in Canada within four years preceding application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documented days of residence (922 days vs. 1095 required)
Harm_Assessment: No legal harm found; decision deemed reasonable
Cause_Description: Li Zhang's citizenship application was denied for not meeting residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: Residency duration assessed quantitatively despite availability of qualitative assessment
Evidence_Issues: Lack of sufficient evidence to establish 1095 days of residence
Evidence_Assessment: Quantitative assessment used due to insufficient days
Decision_Rationale: The judge reasonably concluded that the applicant did not meet the statutory residency requirement, and no reviewable error was found
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to provide adequate proof of required residency duration
